While Just Transition issues apply within developed countries as
well (see later discussion), these are of relatively second
order significance to addressing climate justice
issues between richer and poorer countries
given the scale of financing and exis
in the former and their absence in the latter. For example, over the past three decades drought in Africa
related events combined from the rest of the
hese issues can however serve both as a bridge and a barrier to greater
cooperation on climate change. The key is to build greater mutual trust with clearer commitments and
The Just Transition discussion has picked up steam. It was explicitly recognised in the Paris Agreement
and the 2018 Just Transition Declaration signed
by 53 countries at COP24, which â€˜recognised the need
to factor in the needs of workers and communities to build public support for a rapid shift to a zero
Originally proposed by global trade unions in the 1980s, the recent discourse has
inclusive process to reduce inequality across all three
areas of energy, environment and climate
l sustainability, decent work, social inclusion
livelihoods of communities and workers who stand to lose (including workers in fossil fuel sectors such
as coal and oil and gas)
ticeâ€™ and equity within and across generations, it involves difficult political trade
. The implications for a Just Transition in climate finance are clear:
equitable and greater access to climate finance for vulnerable countries, communities and
for the most profitable private investment opportunities
